Gina quelled them right away. "It's not like that, either. If they spend too long, and I'm talking days here, inside... well, things get complicated. If they don't spend enough time or do it too many times in a short time, they actually speed up the youthening process."

Jen still had questions.
12212111.title: Backstory Bo--er, Girl

1221212.content:
"He said his name was Ronald Guest." Ginnie replied, grinning from ear to ear. "Did you know him?"

         For Jen, the proverbial two and two were at this time nowhere near four. However, they had come up with something, even if it wasn't the right answer. Jen remembered passing the Green Pillow on the stairs and would certainly have remembered a burgeoning belly blocking her path. Gen was upstairs when she got to the room, so one of three things, in her reasoning, MUST be true:

1. There was another stairway and Gen somehow ran back up and back to her room, and lied that it wasn't her she'd passed.

2. Gen and Gina were two parts of a set of triplets.
OR

3. It was Gina she'd passed on the stairs, who had apparently gone out and swallowed one of the other classmates.


         Now obviously, Jen thought, the third choice just can't happen, and the first choice doesn't seem likely, unless Gen could somehow fly. The second choice, while just as unlikely, is the only reasonable answer. She was so caught up in this thought, she didn't hear the first half of the ongoing conversation.

         Gina was saying, "...had half the squad sore for a week. But, we won the next game, so I suppose it wasn't for nothing. Still, don't let Coach Guest catch wind of this. He'll be torked, his son getting in our pants this soon! But hey, good job. Congrats!"

         Gen, oddly enough, was knelt down in front of Ginnie, pushing up on her sister's massive middle and giggling, "Hey Ron, can you hear me? Ronnie?"

         What happened next caused a collection of near-simultaneous gasps. Low in Ginnie's belly, very close to where Gen had been pressing, the clear and distinct outline of a face pressed outward against the distended ball of flesh.
         Ginnie gasped twice in quick succession as if out of breath, her eyes going wide and a half-cocked grin sliding onto her face.
         Gen gasped in surprise at the face so close to her face, and in the next second kissed her sister's belly on the lips.
         Jen gasped in shock as option 3 from before suddenly made itself known, then gasped in horror as Gen actually leaned in and kissed it!

         Gina, who would otherwise have been aloof through the ordeal, gasped in response to Jen's; she realized that this was indeed one of the 'Untold'. And it was Gina who acted next, rather than reacted. She grabbed the door with one hand, Gen with the other, and nudged her into the hallway. "You talk with your sister. I need to talk to Jen." she hurriedly said before closing the door behind her. Then she spun around, wide eyed, to Jen.

         Jen, who had just realized that she was in a cannibalistic insane asylum and in very real danger, took a step back.

         "You don't know, do you?" Gina asked, locking the door behind her. "You don't have a clue!" Her look was either utter fascination or hungry anticipation, Jen couldn't tell. Jen, in response, swallowed deeply.
         "Hah!" Gina interjected, catching Jen off-guard, "You really don't know! God, how did you end up... how could you not know about..."

         Jen was two seconds from crying. She stumbled backward, nearly falling down, whimpering, "Don't eat me, Gina!"
1221212.title: Umberth Blues

choices: What do you mean by complicated?
So why haven't I heard about this before?
12212121.content:
Gina laughed, "No, no wait... Jen just relax... it's not like that at all!" She took another step toward Jen, who took a like step backward, this time falling to the floor.

         Gina took a step backward. "Jen, you're all right! I'm not going to eat you. Wow, you really don't know, do you?" She shook her head, laughing to herself. "Jen, this is Umberth College. It's a school for 'gifted' kids, and cursed ones. The Untold Plague of '64. Man, where do I start?"

         "You're not going to eat me?" Jen whimpered, looking up the way a Holstein does an oncoming freight train. Gina smiled and shook her head no. Jen, while relieved, was still too tense to say anything more for almost a minute. Finally, she asked, "What plague? Polio?"

         Gina pulled out the desk chair and sat down, straddling the seat as if it were a saddle. "Not polio, Jen. That happened in the 50's. I'm talking 1964. Killed a thousand people. Infected hundreds of others. No clue what I'm talking about?"

         "None." Jen replied. While still a bit shook up, the memory of a face pressing out of a girl's belly was being psychologically repressed, which made her feel better. She was already building up the walls needed to convince herself that she was just in a normal dorm room with a normal roommate.

         "None." she repeated, swearing under her breath. "Alrighty then. I guess we should start at the beginning. In 1964, a mysterious virus swept through a small part of New Hampshire and part of Canada. In two weeks time, a hundred people died. In a month, it was more than a thousand, in the US alone."

         "That's a lot of bodies," Jen swallowed, trying to hold the information in.

         "That's the thing. There were no bodies," came Gina's retort, "A whole town, wiped off the map."

         Jen couldn't resist asking, "What do you mean, no bodies?"

         Gina leaned in, "That's the thing. This virus, it didn't attack people physically. It went after them chronologically! It messed with their age!"

         "So, what? They died of old age?"

         "Young age. People got 'younger'. All the way back past infancy. A few that first night even. Some were slower. Some died of exposure, reduced to a baby without anyone to care for them. It was a mess."

         Any sane person would have dismissed this whole story as bunk. Fortunately for us, Jen's recent encounter with Ginnie and the face left her a little worse for wear, and she just nodded, accepting it as fact. "That's horrible." she simply stated.

         "Enter Dr. Lady Umbert. A geneticist. She actually lost her son to the plague, even while she was working on a cure. A cure she found just days late."

         "That's horrible." Jen repeated, to which Gina nodded again. "What does all this have to do with me?"

         "Only everything!" Gina said, suddenly excited. "Her cure was a retrovirus. Yes, even back then. She was able to mutate the virus. For most folk, it slowed the virus almost to a standstill. For a few girls, it took another form. They were cured of the youthening, and became 'un-birthing' receptacles. Do you follow what I'm saying?"

         Jen nodded, then shook her head. "Nope. What in the hell are you talking about?"

         Gina scratched her head a moment before answering. "The retrovirus was slowed, changed from airborne to sexually contracted, but not stopped. People were still getting younger, just slower. Sometimes in spurts. For the few, well, their bodies adapted to fix the problem. We, meaning they, learned to open up and accept people into our bodies. We call it 'unbirthing'. An infected person is returned to their normal age by spending time inside the womb. My mom was one of those gifted with like that. So am I."

         Jen could only blink at the information. A million questions were whizzing around in her head, but no doubts. Despite the insanely outlandish story, she believed. "So, it's like eternal life..." she started, her mind thinking of the possibilities.

         Gina quelled them right away. "It's not like that, either. If they spend too long, and I'm talking days here, inside... well, things get complicated. If they don't spend enough time or do it too many times in a short time, they actually speed up the youthening process."

         Jen still had questions.
12212121.title: All is Revealed by Gina

choices: ... you can't leave- you've become on of the 'Told'.
...I'll help you out when the hallway clears a little.
122121212.content:
After settling onto the bed, Jen impulsively asked, "So why haven't I heard about this before?" Her hands, in an effort to distract, sought something to touch. Her left hand rose to her face, twirling a stray strand of hair on her finger. Her other hand, without thinking, fell into her lap, brushing her belly with one finger.

         As soon as it had, her hand jerked back as if it had been shocked, then fell to her side. Even a repressed memory had a way of altering and affecting what a person does and says. She looked decidedly uncomfortable.

         Gina saw the whole thing, and smiled despite herself. "When the government caught wind of a highly infectious disease in rural New England, what do you suppose they did? Closed the borders, right? Sent in the guys in the shiny suits. Blacked out the media into and out of the area. Threatened to burn the town to the ground. Some people think they were responsible for releasing it in the first place. Accident or no, if Dr. Umbert hadn't found the cure when she did, it would have been a massacre.
         Gina leaned forward for emphasis, "After Dr. Umbert found the cure, the government paid off the victims. No, I'm serious- they created a bullshit story about a freak snowstorm and record low temperatures causing people to die, and paid the families involved never to tell the public-at-large what really happened. They paid for Umberth College, too- as a place for victims and their families to get a 'normal education' and to care for their, and by 'their' I mean 'our' special needs."

         There was a long silence as Jen let the information soak in. Her mouth opened twice, only to close again in a feeble impersonation of a guppy. Then she stood up, walking briskly to the door, turned and pointed at it. "So Gen, and Ginnie, and everyone here... they 'unbirth' each other? I..." she shook her head, her face contorting towards illness, "I mean... how?"

         Gina jumped out of her chair, one leg coming up on the chair, "How?! Jennifer, you can't be serious! How do you think a person gets into a womb? I mean... jeez! Do I need to show you?"

         All at once, the proverbial two and two suddenly and irrevocably equaled four. Jen's look went from disgust to wide-eyed shock, and she slumped to the floor.

         But only for a second. She sprang back up almost as fast as she had fallen. "I need to call my mom..." she said, a determined look on her face. "...I can't stay here." She unlocked and opened the door, prepared to run all the way down the stairs to the phone she saw in the lobby of the dorm.

         Gina jumped up and grabbed her shoulder, "Jen, wait!"

         In the few moments the door had been shut, the hallway had come alive with people. At least twenty girls, some with heavy luggage, some with heavy bellies, were crowding this way and that, pushing past each other to find their dorm rooms. The rush had begun!

         Slamming the door and turning back to Gina, Jen almost screamed, "This is messed up! I mean, besides being very weird, no offense... it's just, this place isn't for me! I don't have any 'youthening' disease. I'm sure as hell not loose enough to push a person's arm into me, much less a full-grown person!"

         "You need to calm down, Jen...
122121212.title: The Cover-up

choices: The phone call doesn't go as expected.
The phone call goes exactly as expected (badly!).
1221212122.content:
Jen finally let herself go, slumping against the door to the floor and bursting into tears. It was all just too much for her.

         "I didn't want to come here to begin with," she said between sobs, "I was doing good in my last school. Better than any of them. I had friends. I hadn't gotten into any fights at all, and I was getting along with all my teachers. Well, most of them, anyway..."

         Gina asked, "What happened?"

         Jen scowled, "Lacey Esterbrook happened. She didn't like the way I sat between her and the window, or how her guy-toys turned their heads when I first came in the first day. She cornered me between classes and punched me so hard in the chest that I couldn't breathe. I broke her nose. Then she lied to the principal and said I attacked her! Since she looked messed up and I didn't, I was expelled. My whole chest turned purple a few days later."

         Gina grimaced. "Deep tissue bruise. Ouch. Wait a minute, you said 'last school'. More than one?"

         "Six. In the last two years. My dad's work moves us around a lot. Makes it hard to keep friends, right?"

         Gina smiled despite herself. "Always the outsider. Always different. I know what you mean," Inside, she thought, The only uninfected girl in a campus full of unbirthees and unbirthers. She shook her head, "It never changes. When I turned 11, my mom said..."

         Gina was interrupted by the sound of chimes coming from an as-yet unknown source, followed by the voice of an older woman, crackling slightly here and there, either from old age or a bad sound system. "Attention students! I, Dean Beatrice Solre, and the rest of the staff would like to take this time to welcome you to another fine year here at Umberth College! I trust all of you have found your rooms by now, and reunited with old and perhaps met a few new friends. Excellent, excellent! It's been a long day for everyone, so I have declared that the Dining Hall will be open between six and eight o'clock for all students, but remember- only singletons will be allowed in. So let them out, they're probably hungry too! And students, please remember to use caution and care, and don't get too carried away. The nurses can only work so fast! Again, welcome back to Umberth!"

         Jen stood quickly when there was a knock on the door, wiping her eyes and trying to make herself presentable. It was Gen. "Hey gang, did you hear that?" she asked as she slid breasts-first through the open door. Jen was about to close the door when Ginger, now an identical twin once again, pushed through. "I don't know about you," Ginnie said, looking at Gen, who then joined her in chorus, "but I'm hungry!" Then they giggled in once voice that seemed to defy logic- when one was resting between chuckles, the other was tittering. It ended sounding more like a single, long 'hee' rather than 'hee hee hee'.

         Gina held up one finger to Jen, letting her know that she wasn't done with her, then spoke to Ginnie, "So, where's your Guest?" Her emphasis was meant to be a joke, considering Ronald Guest had been inside of her.

         Surprisingly, she got the joke. Ginger giggled again, "Ronnie? He said he had to go meet his roomies." This said, she lifted up her sweater slightly and rubbed her trim, neat belly. "God, that felt good! Gen, it was easy, once you get the hang of it. I want to do it again!"

         As Jen blanched, Gen began jumping up and down, "Oh, me me! Do me!"

         Gina stepped over to Jen, putting her arm around her protectively. "You can do that later. You said you were hungry, right?" The other two nodded emphatically, looked at each other, then started tittering again as they rushed out of the room. Gina poked her head out, looking both ways, then back to Jen.

         "Alright Jennifer. The coast is clear. Let's go make that phone call."
1221212122.title: Jen Breaks Down

choices: She has a very strange dream...
She is awakened by the sound of her roomates approaching...
12212121222.content:
It was amazing how fast the dorm had emptied of people, leaving the place as quiet and complacent as before. For Jen, much of her fears about the dark, somewhat forboding hallways had been shattered by all new ones more terrifying than she could imagine. Going down the stairwell seemed like a sigh of relief to her. Soon, she hoped, it would all be just a bad memory. Eventually, with counseling, just a bad dream.

         Gina had her by the hand, guiding the poor shattered psyche that was Jennifer to the ancient-looking phone by the main office. This was the first person she'd met who hadn't known about the Plague. She shook her head sadly. No wonder the general population doesn't know about it. Most people, she guessed, couldn't handle the truth. The two of them stood at the phone for a good 15 seconds before Jen picked up the receiver. After another 15 seconds, she just about put it back on its cradle.

         "Are you going to call or not?" Gina asked, looking at her new friend with concern.

         "What? Oh... yeah. I just..." she stammered, looking at Gina with her eyes welling up again with tears. Gina shot her a 'don't-start-that-again' look, which seemed to work. She put the receiver to her ear and spun the old rotary wheel. And waited.

         click!"Hello?" came the woman's voice.

         Jen took in a sharp intake of breath, "Hello Mom. It's me, Jen."

         There was a pause, with a slight rustling sound. Then, Jen's mother replied, "Hey honey. How are you doing?" Small talk. As if nothing was wrong. Jen wanted to scream.

         She didn't. "Mom... I want- Mom, I have to come home." This time it was her mother's turn to breathe in sharply. "Please, Mommy. I can't stay here."

         Her mother's tone was flat. "You didn't get suspended again, did you?"

         "No." Gina gave her arm a squeeze, as if to say, 'It's all right, I'm here with you.' Jen actually appreciated it, letting her mind for an instant stop thinking that her roommate was a sick, twisted girl.

         Her mother's response was quick. "No way, Jen. We've payed the school for at least the semester. This is your last chance, girl. Don't mess it up." Then she added, whispering, "Your father and I send you our love."

         "No, wait Mom! Please, just lis-" click! A lump in her throat, Jen stood listening to the empty receiver until the dial tone cut in. Slowly letting out the air she just realized she'd been holding since she last spoke, she put the phone back and just stared at it. That was it. She was stuck.

         As she turned and started to walk back toward the stairs, Gina asked, "Jen, are you alright?"

         Jen stopped, turned her head slightly, and said, "I'll be fine."

         "Well, do you want me to come back up..." started Gina, but Jen raised her hand up to stop her.

         "I just want to be alone." she said plainly, then started walking back to the stairs, leaving Gina alone in the foyer. Once out of sight, Jen doubled her pace to her room. Once inside, she quietly shut the door, curled up in the corner of the room, and sobbed herself to sleep.
12212121222.title: Rejections and Reflections

choices: "You deserve it- I'll sleep on the floor."
"No, I want to.  I want to sleep in you."  What was she thinking?
122121212222.content:
Thankfully, Jen was a relatively light sleeper, and not one prone to remembering the vivid dreams her subconscious could sometimes create. This last one was a doozy.

         Instead, she was startled awake at the as yet distant but rapidly thundering steps of the other girls coming back from the Dining Hall. She stood quickly, wiping what was left of the tears from her eyes, then rushed over to her rucksack. She pulled out her CD player and returned to the desk. At least she still had her music, until the batteries went dead, that is. She turned her back from the door.

         Soon enough, she heard a knocking. That was probably Gina, warning her of the oncoming elephant. She wanted to ignore them. To scream for them to go away.

         She did neither, for the door burst open suddenly. And here came the elephant, big and green and swinging her arms about in a heartfelt if painful rendition of the school fight song, 'Carry On to Victory'. A+ for enthusiasm, but D- for style.

         This told Jen several things. First, and probably foremost, was that 'Dining Hall' would be synonymous with 'Pep Rally'. Second, and now that she thought about it, probably more important than the first, was that she wouldn't be signing up for Christmas Caroling. This thought very nearly made her smile, thinking of Gen swinging back and forth, her momentum probably sending her careening into the next caroler.

         But No! This was her black mood, and she was going to milk it for all it had! So there!

         When Gina came in soon afterward, tossed her jacket onto the footboard of the top bunk, and then leaned down to touch the sulking one's shoulder. She quietly asked, "Hey Jen. How are you doing?"

         Jen gave a very unladylike snort, replying, "Oh, just peachy here. Haven't shriveled up and died yet!"

         The results of this were instantaneous. Gina pulled her hand away as if it had been bitten by a poisonous viper, and even Gen stopped singing, her eyes going as wide as her Big Green Pillows. Well, nowhere near that big, but you get the idea.

         Gen stumbled a bit, mumbling a little here and there, before suddenly returning to, "...and Should You Stumble and Fall Behind/We'll Carry You to Vic-toe-ry!"

         Gina leaned very close again, pulling away the earphone to be heard better, so that Jen could feel her breath on her ear, "That wasn't nice. We all know people who did that very thing..."

         "Whatever." Jen replied, turning her back on the duo. Frustrated, Gina pulled herself up to the top bunk, sliding quickly under the covers. It wasn't until she was under the covers that she undid her pants and pulled her shirt off, tossing them into her now open suitcase across the room. She was in just a sports bra, and, Jen hoped, a pair of undies. White, tall granny panties covering anything remotely resembling unbirthing apparatus.

         Gen was nuzzling through her own things now, finally pulling out her toothbrush, towel, and teddy bear. The one was new, probably bought just before coming over. The second was less so, a bit ragged along the edges. The last was a brown longhaired teddy missing an eye and looking as if it had been left for a while out in the rain.

         Jen swallowed hard when she realized that no, the bear had probably spent a lot of time in another wet spot entirely. Humming the fight song again, this time with a toothbrush in her mouth, Gen left the room for the showers and community bathroom down the hall. This gave Gina a good opportunity to speak to Jen again.

         "I brought you half a sandwich," she began, fumbling through the pocket of her jacket until she pulled out a noisy cellophane-wrapped package. She tossed it to Jen, who surprisingly caught it, then tossed it on the desk. Hmmfing, Gina added, "You missed a lot tonight."

         This time Jen did laugh, a hollow, dark one. "Oh great. The 'Play Nice' speech. I suppose I have to watch out for the boys trying to get into my pants." She snorted again. "Watch out or they'll split me like a wishbone."

         "Well yeah, that too but..." she started, then stopped. Frustrated, she peeled back the covers and hopped out of bed, "You know, that's not fair. I'm trying to help you..."

         The other's head snapped up. "Fair? What do you know about fair? I'm trapped here, against my will. I don't want to be here. I shouldn't be here, honestly. God, I'll be laughed at. In all this weird shit, I'm the goofy one!"

         A little angrier now, "Hey, we're working on it. Relax!"

         "Relax?!" exclaimed Jen, "What is this 'we'? You and Perky Wondertatas? I'd rather shrivel up and die!"

         Faster than she could blink, Jen was slapped so hard that it rung in both of their ears for minutes afterward. Gina growled, "Don't EVER say that again! You may not be cursed, but you sure know how to act like a baby!" Jen sat in shocked silence, but finally was about to speak. Gina, sensing that she was losing the situation, interrupted her. "Besides," she said, "I haven't told Gen anything."

         Right on cue, Gen came bounding into the room, clacking her sparkly white choppers and holding her still-dry towel. "You have to sign up to use the showers. You should probably get on that, if you want any hot water." The way she said it, it was obvious that someone had told her that very thing, and she was mimicking.

         Gina started to lean towards Jen, who instinctively leaned back. "She's a good girl," whispered Gina, "and she tries hard. But she's also a gossip. And I have to respect your needs."

         Jen felt like a heel. Gina was right, she had been acting babyish. And despite her rudeness, Gina had still been kind enough to respect her. It was odd, really- not something she was used to.

         Gen didn't hear any of this. Instead, she looked at Gina, who was in fact NOT wearing granny panties. Or ANY panties, for that matter. "Oh hey, who gets 'third bed'?" she asked, as if it had just come to her.

         It took a moment for Jen to realize what was being talked about. "Two beds," she murmured, "three roommates." Her eyes started to widen.

         Gen continued, "I still don't think I could take either one of you. We know Gina can. But hey, Jen, if you're feeling up to it..." Jen's eyes bulged more.

         Again it was Gina to the rescue, "You two are rookies. I don't want to have to spend half the night in the nurses office. I'll be third bed."

         "So who gets to sleep in it?" A horribly sweet smile emerged from Gen's lips, and she was about to call 'dibs', when she looked over to Jen. Now, despite the fact that God had given Genveive Ramsey a small portion of brain and large portion of breast, she was also gifted with a big heart. And here was a roommate who obviously hadn't been feeling well, first day jitters and all that. But she so wanted to sleep there herself! "Okay, we'll play a game for it!" She looked around the room with a look of utter concentration, occasionally mouthing numbers as if trying to count in her head. Her eyes stopped on her own breasts, and she looked up, smiling. "Okay, give me a number between one and..." she looked back at her chest as if recounting, "two."

         This was too much. Jen just couldn't help herself. Even in as sour a mood as she was, she had to giggle a little, "Uh, two Gen. I'm guessing two."

         "Hey, that's right! I guess you get the comfy bed tonight!" That said, she turned and ducked for the bottom bunk.

         Gina grabbed for her, ending up with a handful of breast. Funny how hands seem to gravitate there... anyway, she pulled her back up, "I want the bottom bunk." she said hesitantly.

         Gen looked puzzled, "But I thought you wanted the top?"

         Gina thumbed over towards Jen, "With her inside me? What if I fell out of bed?" The other thought of this for a moment, then smiled broadly and nodded emphatically. Giving Gina a wink, she climbed up onto the top bunk. Gina shook her head sadly and turned back to Jen.

         "Do you want the bottom bunk?" she asked Jen, surprising her. "I know you probably don't want to go, you know..." Jen, who was still contemplating real friendship for perhaps the first time ever, shook her head no. "I figured. So do you want the bottom bunk?"

         "No," Jen said at last,
122121212222.title: Sometimes, a Baby Needs to be Slapped

choices: She can't sleep for the cold, and finally accepts her fate and asks for help fro
1221212122221.content:
Gina nodded slowly. She felt sorry for Jen, but not for the readily apparent reasons. Sure, she came from a hard life. But then, who hadn't? Yes, she had found herself stuck in a situation that was out of her control. Again, such was life everywhere. The girl had a hard time making friends, between her constant moving between schools and her slightly abrasive personality.

         Even that, really, wasn't the reason she felt sorry for the girl. She tossed her jacket to the girl who spreading herself out on the floor. "I've been at Umberth for going on three years now, and if there is one thing I've learned, the closer you get to the floor, the colder its going to be. That's why I wanted the top bunk."

         Jen looked up at the mousey blonde, grabbed the jacket, and pulled it up over herself. "Now you tell me," she mused, feeling a cold breeze from the old windows blowing directly over her chest and arms. "But I'll be alright."

         Jen nodded as she said that, as if to reaffirm her situation. She would be alright. One semester, low profile. As long as they don't ask her to do anything weird, like suck up another person into my pussy, she mused, she'd be fine. Sure. She shivered, then sat up and looked Gina in the eyes. "So how often have you gotten the top bunk?" she asked.

         "Well, counting tonight, never." Gina replied with a smile.

         Jen opened her mouth to say something, then thought better of it. Then, changing her mind yet again, she blurted, "So why didn't you insist on it this time?"

         The smile never left Gina's mouth, "I did," she replied, "but something came up that was more important."

         "What?" Jen replied compulsively.

         "A friend who needed me more than I needed the top bunk." Gina said, never wavering in her smile. Then she turned over to face the wall. "If you need me, you know where to find me," she added quietly, settling down to sleep.

         She was cold. And Alone. And in the entire girl's dorm, one full of new students and old, her room was the only one that fell silent. She could still hear people talking, giggling, and moaning well after 3am, when her body finally gave over to tiredness.
1221212122221.title: It's Cold on the Bottom
